image1584√ó396 38.3 KB

Welcome to YETI Robotics' SystemCore Alpha Testing and Offseason Rebuild Thread!

As one of the teams selected for the first wave of SystemCore alpha testing, we‚Äôre excited to share our journey with the future robot controller along with our strategic redesign throughout the 2025 offseason.

Who are We? ìáº ‚ãÜÔΩ°Àö ìÜù‚ãÜÔΩ°Àö ìáº

We are FRC team 3506 YETI Robotics, a community based team located in Charlotte, North Carolina, formed in 2010. Our team is a part of the Queen City Robotics Alliance (QCRA), a non-profit organization we helped found, that supports Charlotte area FIRST teams.

Currently we are in our off-season after a successful 2025 season where we won the FIRST Impact Award at UNC Asheville and the North Carolina District Championship, along with the Team Sustainability Awards in our division at the FIRST World Championship.

Progress with SystemCore Testing ‡Ω≤‡æÄ:ÔΩ•Ôæü

So far we‚Äôve tried to eliminate our use of an OrangePi for vision processing by running Photon Vision on Systemcore, but based on another team‚Äôs testing where one camera with a 2D AprilTag pipeline made the CPU usage jump from 25-30% to 65-70%. We decided that our 2 cameras that use 3D pipelines would be smoother on our OrangePi and keep the CPU usage on the main robot controller low.

GitHub

PhotonVision on SystemCore ¬∑ wpilibsuite SystemCoreTesting ¬∑ Discussion #84

Just sharing my experience getting PhotonVision running on SystemCore. Installation is very simple, just copy the PhotonVision JAR onto the device and create a systemd service to run it as root. Wi...

More on our SystemCore adventures, we‚Äôre planning on testing the necessity of a CANivore. Our team has all the motors and sensors that are a part of our drivetrain on a separate CANbus added by the CANivore to improve speed and control when driving, as well as to protect the drivetrain in case any devices on the main CANbus break. We‚Äôd like to test whether or not using a CANivore or 2 CANchains on SystemCore works better. A major problem we faced this season with the roboRIO was CPU usage issues due to vision processing. The SystemCore is much more powerful compared to the roboRIO and we are testing if those issues will be solved with the new robot controller.

A lot of our work with SystemCore as of now is preparing for it to be used on our competition robot for offseason events. As a team, we are focusing on training rookies and undergoing a strategic redesign of our REEFSCAPE robot, Beluga, that incorporates SystemCore and is more competitive for said events.

Keep in mind we won‚Äôt have regular updates due to SystemCore not being on the robot yet!

Robot Redesign ‚úßÀö.

In addition to the electrical changes brought about by SystemCore, we plan to re-wire a lot of the robot for cleaner wire management and as practice for new members of the team. We‚Äôve designed a new end effector for our offseason competitions after many strategic redesign workshops. This end effector is meant to give us both coral and algae capabilities using super-pinch, something we weren‚Äôt able to fully utilize during the actual season. We are trying it with a 20:1 gear ratio on the intake rollers for torque to pinch algae.

Below are some images of our robot intaking various gamepieces.

Intaking ALGAE1065√ó855 145 KB

Intaking CORAL749√ó654 93.3 KB

On the programming side of our team, we are rewriting our auto-align code, which is crucial for fast cycles in this game, and creating a simulation sandbox for future robot projects. Simulation is a tool we heavily utilized this season, for anything from camera placements to logic for our game piece manipulator system. We were able to simulate camera feeds using PhotonVision and AdvantageScope‚Äôs 3D Field, which greatly sped up our programming process. With a custom 3D model of our robot, we were able to quickly test logic code despite its four degrees of freedom.

Our first offseason event is SCRAP, in Camden, South Carolina on August 23rd. Stay tuned for more updates and please ask questions below!

Quick Update on SystemCore!

Before our first offseason competition, SCRAP, next Saturday (August 23rd) in Camden, South Carolina, we'd like to give an update on one of the issues we encountered with SystemCore.

The Magnetic Limit Switch ìÜù ìÜü ìÜû ìÜù ìÜü

On our competition robot, we use a magnetic limit switch at the bottom of our elevator because we decided not to put CANcoders onto our elevator motors. However, once we made the switch from our RoboRIO 2.0 to SystemCore, we found there was no change in signal when connected to the new robot controller.

MagSwitch setup1346√ó1007 189 KB

We proceeded to test multiple ports, verified the magnet being detected by the switch, verified the signal wire changes voltage with the magnet (3.3V which is within the range on the spec sheet), and also that the switch works on the RIO with a test board.

Below is the panel showing red and ‚ÄúX‚Äù when we tested out the IO by putting in bare wire, shorting the power and ground pins of a port. We fixed this fault with a power cycle. Normally, the red light is off. It only turns on when there is some kind of fault. It‚Äôs pretty cool being able to see exactly which port is faulting!

Red IO light :c1920√ó2560 400 KB

The internal resistor inside SystemCore is a 4.7kŒ© pull down resistor compared to a 40kŒ© pull up resistor on the RIO. After opening an issue on Github, Thad House confirmed our suspicions that the lack of value changing was very likely due to the pull down resistor. He speculated the sensor was built with a pull up in the signal path, and used an NPN style transistor setup. This problem could be fixed by adding a resistor to the circuit, but we did not have one on hand. This suggests that many of our common powered sensors we have now may not work with the internal pull down resistor.

github.com/wpilibsuite/SystemCoreTesting

REV Magnetic Limit Switch not being read on SystemCore Smart I/O ports

opened 10:56PM - 16 Aug 25 UTC
taran-duba

Hi all, We are running a Rev Magnetic limit switch on our robot with SystemCore‚Ä¶ and are having an issue with the boolean reading not changing. We‚Äôve tested on multiple ports, verified the mag switch is detecting the magnet, verified the signal wire changes voltage (3.3V) with the magnet, verified it works on the rio with a test board. There‚Äôs no change in boolean signal when connected to SystemCore. We‚Äôve read here that the internal resistor is a 4.7kOhm pull down resistor in syscore vs a 40kOhm pull up resistor on the rio. when running power to syscore the multimeter reads 3.3 volts. we think this should just mean the value is inverted? but it may be causing this lack of value changing too. Has anyone experienced this before?

After asking in the Unofficial FRC Discord, we were told that 3.3V inverters and a 1/8 W 1k pull up resistor or a 3.3V buffer and a pull up resistor would work as a solution. The next hardware version of SystemCore will have a different internal resistor, which may make it more compatible with more existing sensors.

GitHub

IO pull-up vs pull-down ¬∑ wpilibsuite SystemCoreTesting ¬∑ Discussion #120

It looks like the digital IOs are configured to pull down, as opposed to the pull-ups on the RIO. Is this subject to change in future iterations of the hardware? Keeping interoperability with the R...

We then replaced the magnetic limit switch with a physical limit switch as a temporary solution since that is just a simple electrical switch.

Current temporary setup for competition1208√ó901 83.8 KB

Public Scouting Data from Worlds and FNC!

We scout at every event we go to and make sure to provide all data publicly on our Github.

Throughout the last year we submitted over 3,000 forms with ~48,000 data points. Our dataset is 100% COMPLETE for the Galileo Division at Worlds, and we also have lots of data from FIRST North Carolina State Championship, FNC District Mecklenburg County Event, and FNC District UNC Asheville Event.

ALL of our past scouting data (not just REEFSCAPE!) is available here:

Excited for SystemCore testing results,

Roborio‚Äôs I2C port has sync issues with rev i2c sensors.
Is it working with Systemcore ?

We do not use any REV I2C sensors, however the REV control/expansion hub was mentioned in another discussion about SystemCore‚Äôs internal resistor. I2C devices are also mentioned in a discussion about SPI functionality. These were just on the SystemCore Github, not sure if it‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for.

SystemCore At Offseason Competition SCRAP

This past Saturday (8/23), we took SystemCore to SCRAP (South Carolina Robotics and Practicals)! Overall, it worked very well and we‚Äôre super grateful that the FIRST South Carolina team let us test on the field before their practice matches.

This allowed us to verify some crucial connections including initializing the autonomous period, A-stopping, initializing the teleoperating period and being able to drive, and finally emergency stopping. The FMS had connected fine in our subsequent matches although there was a network handshake issue at the start of one which didn‚Äôt seem to be due to SystemCore.

Connection Issue

At the start of one of our matches the SystemCore and radio connection failed, the FMS could talk to the radio but the radio couldn‚Äôt reach SystemCore. The radio and ethernet IP addresses did not seem abnormal, which we were able to quickly check via the screen that was very helpful throughout the day with the IP not being static.

What fixed the issue was unplugging the ethernet cable from SystemCore and plugging it back in. SCRAP‚Äôs FTAs suspected it was simply a network handshake issue that could normally be seen on RIOs and would usually be fixed with the reset button. We know many teams have brought up the lack of a physical reset button as a concern, this FTA had looked for that button when troubleshooting and requested it be brought back on future versions.

Logging with SystemCore

When trying to go over logs after a match, we found they currently do not go to the Driver Station and couldn‚Äôt be downloaded through Phoenix Tuner. Only the CTRE hoot files were available there and we were trying to look at Epilogue files. However, the file names (which were dynamic and random strings with the prefix ‚ÄúFRC_‚Äù when we weren‚Äôt connected to FMS) were able to be found in systemctl under robot.service and retrieved using scp.

Reception

A lot of the other teams at SCRAP as well as the CSA and FTAs were super excited to see SystemCore on a robot and competing. We had 3d printed a sign which did encourage many people to come up to our pit curious about the new controller. Testing SystemCore at SCRAP was a success and we look forward to taking it to our next event SCRIW (South Carolina Robotics Invitational & Workshops) on October 11th!

SCRAP Pit782√ó1163 130 KB

Yeah it‚Äôs super compact, we were shocked how much space we saved. We originally had our orange pi housed on top of the RIO and then the CANivore on top of that, but now they all get to sit nicely on the belly pan. We‚Äôre actually doing a new build for SCRIW based on Rocky so you‚Äôll see that there!

We have the same Issue, I was working on the systemcore and try to see how the software grabs the Ethernet stuff or even try plug in with usb directly, it shows as linux device and not really reaching it. I don‚Äôt think that it isn‚Äôt passing but it reads it differently, I think there is some a way to fix it but I don‚Äôt know yet. Limelight or other Protonvision did not officially posted about supporting systemcore yet so I was just thinking about using Ni RoboRio 2 instead of systemCore until they have documentation on it.
